Package de.hshl.obj.wavefront.parse

Interface Resource.Environment

  • Enclosing class:
    Resource
    public static interface Resource.Environment
    A Environment is able to open a resource by name. This interface abstracts away the difference between JAR resources and file resources, and also allows to read OBJ contents from memory.

    The Environment represents the folder where your OBJ file resides in. This interface is required because OBJ files will need to look for MTL files not only in the same directory but possibly also in the same JAR resource folder.
    Author:
    Johannes Vollmer
    See Also:
    Resource

      static Resource.Environment folder​(java.nio.file.Path folder)
      The Environment representing the specified directory.

      If this Environment is made from a folder path, returns the path.
      static Resource.Environment local​(java.nio.file.Path resourceFolder)
      The Environment representing the specified subdirectory in this JAR package or a local file if the JAR resource cannot be found.
      java.io.BufferedReader openResource​(java.lang.String name)
      Open the specified resource inside this Resource.Environment

    • Method Detail

      • openResource

        java.io.BufferedReader openResource​(java.lang.String name)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Open the specified resource inside this Resource.Environment
        Parameters:
        name - Specified the resource to open
        Returns:
        The opened resource. Must be closed by the caller.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If the resource cannot be opened

      • getFolderPath

        @Nullable
default java.nio.file.Path getFolderPath()
        If this Environment is made from a folder path, returns the path. Otherwise, returns null.

      • folder

        static Resource.Environment folder​(@Nullable
                                   java.nio.file.Path folder)
        The Environment representing the specified directory.

      • local

        static Resource.Environment local​(@Nullable
                                  java.nio.file.Path resourceFolder)
        The Environment representing the specified subdirectory in this JAR package or a local file if the JAR resource cannot be found.
        Parameters:
        resourceFolder - The sub-folder where the local resource is located, or null if the resource is in the root directory.
        See Also:
        ClassLoader.getResourceAsStream(String)
